section-block.rac_essential-question: Who are the people who help in our community?

section-block.rac_book_title_byline: Written and illustrated by Oge Mora
section-block.rac_book_summary: Omu makes a pot of delicious stew. The smell goes down the hall and around the block. Soon, the neighbors are knocking at her door.

section-block.rac_body-text: Ask children what they know about apartment buildings. How are they different from houses? How are they the same?
Have children sing “The Wheels on the Bus.” As they sing, have them pretend to be the bus driver.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read Thank You, Omu! by Oge Mora.
Scout really likes stories with beautiful pictures. Pictures are also called illustrations.
There is a question I want you to think about as we read. We will talk about it after we read. Ready?
Why did so many people knock on Omu’s door?

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the book and the Day 1 prompts.
Use Equity Sticks to choose children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: The writer and illustrator Oge Mora made illustrations for this book by cutting up pieces of paper. She glued them on another paper and added paint. What shapes can you see in the cut-out pieces of paper?
Look at the picture of Omu cooking a pot of stew. Have you ever eaten stew before?
pages 4–5
Can you predict, or guess, what is coming out of the pot and blowing out of the window?
The little boy knocked on Omu’s door because of a “delicious smell.”
Is that a good smell? Can you think of other foods that smell delicious?
What do you think will happen next in the story?
Let’s turn and talk about the guiding question:
Why did so many people knock on Omu’s door?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk.Then, pick 2–3 children with Equity Sticks to share their thinking.
Possible responses:
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: They wanted to eat some stew.

section.rac_body-text: Write and read aloud short sentences about Omu’s stew as children watch and listen.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Did they smell something delicious or something bad?
Which people showed up at Omu’s door?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Books like Thank You, Omu! with repetition and rhyme are great opportunities to help children learn to make predictions. They help children gain practice in using comprehension strategies, including listen and remember, use background knowledge, make an inference, make a connection, draw a smart conclusion, and ask questions.

section-block.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule_day_2: Share the Mind Builder: Take Another Perspective
section-block.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Omu’s neighbors smelled her stew and knocked on her door because they wanted something to eat. At first, they were thinking of themselves. Later, they were thinking of Omu. When we care about what someone else thinks and feels, we are taking another perspective.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to revisit the book Thank You, Omu! by Oge Mora. We will talk about taking another perspective.
This story is a narrative with characters who could be real people. They act just like real people. We call this a realistic narrative. Who can say that?

section.rac_column_heds_with_rule: Close-Read: Connect to the Mind Builder
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Let’s reread and talk about some pages of the story to notice the Mind Builder, take another perspective, in action.
section.rac_body-text: Use Equity Sticks to pick children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Omu thinks to herself, “It would not hurt to share.” What does she mean?
When the police officer comes to the door, is she thinking about herself or about Omu? Is she thinking about her perspective or Omu’s perspective? (MB)
The hot dog vendor said “Ooooo, stew!” and ate some of Omu’s stew. Is he thinking about his perspective or Omu’s perspective? (MB)
The little boy told Omu that they were there to give. Whose perspective are the neighbors thinking of now: their own perspective or Omu’s perspective? How do you know? (MB)
At the end of the story everyone ate, danced, and celebrated together.
What did each person bring to Omu’s apartment?

section.rac_body-text: Challenge children to think about their own perspectives and compare them to their classmates’ perspectives. Have children gather in small groups based on favorite color, favorite food, favorite book, favorite game, and favorite song. Encourage children to express their differences in complete sentences. For example: My favorite food is macaroni and cheese, and Lisa’s favorite food is mashed potatoes.
Encourage children to draw a picture that shows something that a friend likes to do.
Transcribe children’s speech as they talk about what their friends enjoy doing.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: In preschool, children start to realize that we each have different feelings and experiences. They start to care about others, yet they can continue to confuse their own feelings with those of others. You can help by talking about your feelings and the feelings of characters in books. (Clark/speechandlanguagekids.com, 2019)

section-block.rac_body-text: Remind children that to make an inference means to make a smart guess.
Show different emotions on your face and have children guess what you are feeling. Tell children that they are making an inference with their responses.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to reread the book Thank You, Omu!
Scout likes Thank You, Omu! because he enjoys stories about people who live in cities.

section.rac_guiding-question_blue: There is a question I want you to think about as we read. We will talk about it after we read. Ready?
Who are some of the people in Omu’s community?

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the book and the Day 3 prompts.
Use Equity Sticks to choose children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Omu seasoned and stirred her stew.
What did she use to stir her stew? What does seasoned mean?
When Omu told the little boy the delicious smell was stew, he said, “Mmmmm. Stew! That sure sounds yummy!” What did Omu think the boy wanted? Did she make an inference about what the boy wanted?
Omu asked the police officer, “Would you like some?” and the police officer nodded. When you nod your head up and down, do you mean yes or no? Let’s all nod.
“Mr. Hot Dog Vendor!” Omu exclaimed when she saw the hot dog vendor standing at her door.
Why do you think Omu exclaims when she opens her door? Do you think she knew the hot dog vendor was coming? Who can tell me what a hot dog vendor does?
Look at the pictures on these pages. Can you name all of the different people you see?
Let’s turn and talk about the guiding question.
Who are some of the people in Omu’s community?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk. Then, pick 2–3 children with Equity Sticks to share responses.
Possible responses:
Share a pen with children as you work together to write about the people in Omu’s community, inviting children to add end punctuation.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Is there a police officer or a firefighter in Omu’s community?
There is a police officer in Omu’s c___________ (community).
There is a police officer in Omu’s community.
Who are the people in our school community?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Multilingual learners will often need help with culturally-specific concepts. In this book, children may be unfamiliar with concepts such as living in an apartment building, a hot dog vendor, and a cab driver. Introduce children to the setting using pages (pages 2–5). Discuss what they see in each block and what the illustrations are made of.

section-block.rac_teacher-talk_blue: There are people in our community who have important jobs. Let’s name some of the people who help us in our community.
section-block.rac_body-text: Have pairs of children act out different jobs of people who help us (e.g., doctor, firefighter). Have the rest of the children guess which job they are acting out.

section.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule: Share the Big Chart of Big Ideas
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read Super Jobs. It is a poster that gives us information. We call it an informational poster. Let’s say that!
Scout loves to look at posters! He wants to learn new information about people in our community.
Thank You, Omu! and Super Jobs show us people who help us. Let’s see if we can find any connections between the two.
section.rac_hilight_teacher_inst_new: Show Thank You, Omu! book cover.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: As we read the Big Chart, let’s think about how it connects to this week’s concept question:
Who are the people who help in our community?

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the back of the Big Chart. Then use these prompts to discuss.
Use Equity Sticks during reading to pick children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Who can tell me the two reasons why we visit a doctor?
Who can point to the plumber? What is the plumber doing? How do plumbers help us? What do they fix?
What kinds of foods does a baker make? Have you ever made cookies? A cake? Let’s pretend we are rolling dough on a counter.
How do firefighters help us? How do they keep us safe?
How does a police officer keep us safe?

section.rac_body-text: Have children choose the job of a community helper that they would like to do. Then have them draw a picture of that job. Help children add labels to their drawings. Ask volunteers to tell the rest of the class about their drawing and how that job helps the community.
Provide a writing prompt about community helpers and give ongoing feedback as children draw and write in response to the prompt.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Preschool children learn social studies concepts by observing and discussing their surroundings: homes, banks, libraries, fire stations, playgrounds, parks, and stores. Encourage children to compare their neighborhood to those in books, taking note of similarities and differences.

section-block.rac_body-text: Have children act out the story of Thank You, Omu! Show page 3 (Omu stirring her stew), page 7 (the little boy knocking on Omu’s door), page 12 (the police officer at Omu’s door), page 15 (Omu giving the police officer stew), pages 24–26 (Omu looking at her empty pot), page 30 (the neighbors bringing food), and page 31 (celebrating inside Omu’s tiny apartment).

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to retell and reenact the book Thank You, Omu! written and illustrated by Oge Mora.
This book is a realistic narrative. It’s not a true story, but the people look and act like real people. Scout likes reading about people.

This week we read about a woman named Omu who made a stew for her supper. People in the neighborhood came knocking on her door asking her what smelled so delicious. As I read the book one more time, I want you to think about this guiding question:
Why did Omu and her neighbors share their food with each other?

section.rac_d-hed_page_number: Reread and retell the book together. Use Equity Sticks to pick children to actively participate in the prompts.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What did Omu do after she finished cooking her stew? When in the day do we eat supper?
What is Omu doing? Why did she decide to share her stew with the boy?
So far in the story, who has Omu shared her stew with? Let’s count!
All of Omu’s neighbors entered her apartment with something to give.
What did each person bring?
page 31
Omu was sad that she had no dinner left until her neighbors came and ate, danced, and celebrated with her.
Stand up and show me how you would celebrate with Omu!

section.rac_body-text: Invite children to turn and talk with a partner about the guiding question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: Why did Omu and her neighbors share their food with each other?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk. Then pick 2–3 children with Equity Sticks to share their responses.
Possible responses:
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: They wanted to be kind to Omu for sharing her food with them.
Omu wanted to share her stew.

section.rac_body-text: Invite children to draw or write about something they share with their friends.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Did Omu think she had enough food to share or too little?
Omu thought she had enough food to sh_______ (share).
Omu thought she had enough food to share.
How did the neighbors’ perspectives change?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: One of the key predictors of children’s academic achievement is their vocabulary. Developing children’s knowledge of sophisticated words in preschool is critical to a child’s success in school and in life. Children love learning “big words.” Using words like delectable, scrumptious, and exclaimed will build a strong foundation for life.
